caseTitle: RULES OF PRACTICE OR PROCEDURE [1989-90] VOL XVII RGL 261—27
summary: The document examines a key jurisdictional issue in Ghanaian procedural law concerning the Supreme Court's power under Rule 66(1) of the Supreme Court Rules, 1970 (CI 13) to waive non-compliance with Rule 13(1), which mandates filing a statement of case within three weeks of notification that the record of appeal is ready. In *Darke XII v Dei XI*, the Supreme Court, by a 3-2 majority, held that Rule 66(1) grants the Court jurisdiction to waive non-compliance and restore an appeal struck out under Rule 13(2), interpreting 'action' to include appellate proceedings. However, on the same day, in *In re Oppong (Decd)*, a differently constituted bench, by another 3-2 majority, held the opposite—Rule 66(1) applies only to original jurisdiction actions, not appeals—without addressing the earlier *Darke* decision. The document critiques the *Oppong* ruling as *per incuriam* due to failure to consider binding precedent under Article 116(3) of the 1979 Constitution and highlights internal inconsistency, especially given Rule 70's definition of 'party' to include parties to appeals.
verdict: In Darke XII v Dei XI, the application was dismissed on merits but jurisdiction under Rule 66(1) was affirmed; in In re Oppong (Decd), jurisdiction was denied, creating conflicting rulings.
winningSide: In Darke XII v Dei XI: respondents (on merits); in In re Oppong (Decd): respondents (on jurisdiction)

caseType: Procedural Appeal / Application for Extension of Time
rationaleHighlights: Rule 66(1) uses 'any provisions of these Rules', suggesting broad applicability including appellate rules.
'Action' should be interpreted in its commonsense legal meaning to include both original and appellate proceedings.
Rule 70 defines 'party' to include 'party to an appeal', undermining a narrow reading of 'action'.
Failure to consider Darke in Oppong renders the latter decision per incuriam.
Jurisdictional conflict arises from two differently constituted benches deciding the same issue oppositely on the same day.
The interests of justice support discretionary power to waive procedural defaults where non-wilful.
A rigid interpretation risks injustice where technical default bars meritorious appeals.
The Supreme Court's authority to manage its docket supports flexible interpretation of procedural rules.
